description.narrative:
Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till organisationen Open Government Partnership om totalt 45 MSEK under en treårsperiod 2019-2021.
Open Government Partnership är ett multi-intressent-initiativ som startade 2011 med syfte att övertyga regeringar om insatser för att främja öppenhet, stärka medborgarinflytande bekämpa korruption och använda gemensamt utvecklade metoder för att stärka samhällsstyrningen. Open Government Partnership består för närvarande av 79 nationella och 20 lokala regeringar och ett tusental civilsamhällesorganisationer. För att bli medlem i Open Government Partnership måste regeringar uppfylla de villkor som är uppställda, göra ett offentligt uttalande om öppenhet, utverka en nationell handlingsplan med hjälp av medborgarkonsultationer och rapportera utvecklingen med hjälp av den oberoende översynsmekanism som finns i initiativet.
Open Government Partnerships vision är formulerad som att "fler regeringar ska bli mer transparenta, mer ansvarstagande och mer lyhörda för sina medborgares deltagande med slutgiltigt mål att förbättra styrning och samhällsservice". Arbetet kretsar kring nationella handlingsplaner som tas fram i en gemensam process mellan regeringar och civila samhället. Open Government Partnership arbetar utifrån en strategi som uppdaterades 2016 och utgör vägledning för verksamheten. Strategin kommer att utvecklas under 2019 för att med utgångspunkt i nuvarande vision formulera vägar för att nå bättre genomslag fram till 2022.
Strategin omfattar följande områden: 1) Ökat fokus på medborgarcentrerad samhällsstyrning 2) Breddat gemensamt ägarskap för nationella handlingsplaner 3) Ökad ambitionsnivå och lärande 4) Stärkt kapacitet, koordinering och nätverk för genomförande 5) Översyn av incitaments- och regelstruktur 6) Stärkt varumärke och kommunikationsstrategi
Total budget för 2019 är ca 12,4 MUSD. Budgetarna för 2020 och 2021 är uppskattade till 13,4 MUSD. Total budget är ca 39,2 MUSD. Sidas bidrag utgör knappt 10 %.

The intervention concerns a core support of 45 MSEK during the three-year period 2019-2021.
The Open Government Partnership (OGP) is a multi-stakeholder initiative established in 2011 aimed at securing commitments from governments to promote transparency, empower citizens, fight corruption and harness new technologies to strengthen governance. OGP currently comprises of 79 national and 20 local governments and some thousand civil society organisations. To become a member of OGP, governments must meet OGP's elibility criteria, endorse a high-level Open Government Declaration, deliver a National Action Plan (NAP) developed through public consultations, and commit to independent reporting on their progress through the Independent Review Mechanism (IRM).
OGP is directed by a strategy for 2015-2018 that was "refreshed" in 2016 to more clearly articulate the vision and identify the best means to work for that. By early 2020 OGP will complete a medium-term planning process, with the goal of developing a three-year implementation plan and budget (2020-2022). This implementation plan will not lay out a new vision for OGP but will focus on collective results that are aimed to be achieved in three years and how this will happen.
The strategy focusses on the following areas: 1) Deepen citizen-centered gocvernance 2) Broaden collective ownership of OGP domestically 3) Raise collective ambition, peer exchange and learning across OGP countries 4) Strengthen capacity, coordination and coalitions for implementation 5) Review performance incentives and rules of engagement 6) Strengthen the OGP brand and communications strategy
The total budget for 2019 is about 12.4 MUSD. The budgets for 2020 and 2021 are estimated to 13.4 MUSD respectively. Total budget amounts to approximately 39.2 MUSD. Sida's contribution constitutes a little less than 10 % for each year.

title.narrative: 12572 Agreement Sida and Open Government partnership

description.narrative:
In its three-year implementation plan 2020-2022, OGP formulates its strategic approaches as follows:
1. Stronger Universal OGP Platform (including knowledge and learning, OGP local expansion and IRM refresh)
2. Priority Commitments (focussed support to 12 ambitious commitments)
3. Priority Countries (focused support to 12 countries)
4. Priority Themes (anti-corruption/beneficial ownership, Citizens shaping public services, Digital governance, Opening justice, Civic space and Gender & inclusion)
5. Priority Global (Leverage global platforms such as IACC, IODC, SDGs, OGP 10th anniversary, Campaigns on cross-cutting issues).
The strategic approaches are structured in a way that provide a good tool for OGP to steer its work.
In the first half of 2020, OGP developed a three-year implementation plan for 2020-2022 in discussion with its stakeholders. At first, it was not clearly communicated how this implementation plan relates to the strategic refresh of 2016. After clarifying conversations in 2020 between Sida and OGP, it was established that the three year implementaiton plan is an annual implementation plan with activities for 2020, but with a mid-term perspective so that tentative plans for the coming years are also established. During the same conversations, OGP clarified the RBM framework and provided details on the indicators used to track results. Sida, as a partner providing core support, wants to align to OGP reporting as much as possible.
In its annual reporting for the year of 2020, OGP demonstrates an improved capacity for reporting with greater clarity in reference to activities and results and the report is an enjoyable read. During the annual meeting in September between Sida and OGP, Sida will emphasize the benefit of focusing increasingly on lessons learned in the RBM feedback loop. The OGP has also agreed to clarify some details in relation to the Theory of Change during the annual meeting, especially because of OGPs request for a cost extension for the year of 2022.
OGP annual reports is intended to align with OGP progress indicators 2020-2022 (attached). These indicators are aligned with the 3 Year Implementation Plan and are central to how OGP tracks progress. In this way, the supplemental information on indicators provides a quantitiative basis for conclusions drawn in the annual report.
In reference to its progress tracking, OGP explains:
- OGPs progress indicators are quantitative, and at the output/short-term outcomes level. They are proxies for key elements of OGPs Theory of Change, in that they capture OGPs activities in building the political incentives, relationships, skills, and capacities of reformers so that they can individually and collectively commit to ambitious reforms in their action plans and proceed to implement them for results. These indicators therefore, are stepping stones and help OGP understand incremental progress made towards the longer-term impact of securing concrete reforms in the countries.
- OGPs Independent Reporting Mechanism (IRM) complements activity level and output level data from the OGP Support Unit by reporting on longer term outcomes and results. IRM progress reports assess countries on the development and implementation of OGP action plans and progress in fulfilling open government principles as well as making technical recommendations for improvements. The IRM generates a large amount of data from OGPs 78 member countries which is then aggregated and analyzed along dimensions such as ambition, completion, and results of policy areas such as anti-corruption, public service delivery, etc. The combination of these two sources of Support Unit data and IRM data helps to build a picture of the causal chain from inputs, outputs, outcomes, and impacts.
OGP also collects qualitative data by focusing on a subset of countries every year, which helps to bring contextual richness to OGPs activities and highlights the reformers on the ground who are supposed to be benefiting from OGPs activities. An additional source for OGPs progress data is also an ongoing independent developmental evaluation of OGP which began in 2019. The evaluation is assessing the relevance, effectiveness, efficiency and impact of the OGP platform. The countries being studied are Colombia, Nigeria, Ukraine, the Philippines, South Cotabato, Kenya, and Elgeyo-Marakwet County. The policy areas being studied in these countries are beneficial ownership, open contracting, and citizen engagement. Sida will follow up on this evaluation and how its findings will be used to furhter srenghten the organisation's activities.
Key results
2020 was a rather successful year for OGP, with one of the highlights being that 94 countries and thousands of people were represented in OGPs "Open Response Open Recovery" virtual events. In addition, 5 heads of state and open government leaders from 23 countries participated in the Virtual Leaders Summit.
Other highlights reported:
• 15 members submitted action plans • 11 major knowledge products were published providing resoursces, reform examples, and stories of OGP members. • 56 new OGP Local members • 33,600 uses of #OpenGov on Twitter • 39,000 engagements with the "Open Response Open Recovery" campaign on Twitter
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
